text:
Making Dried Fruit Cornucopia Soup Combine all dried fruits, tapioca, grape juice, and water in a slow cooker.  Cover and cook on low for 8 hours.  Before serving, stir in orange and lemon juices, orange peel, and brown sugar.  Serve. Depending on the time of year, serve as preferred:
Serve warm as soup or dessert. Serve chilled with frozen vanilla yogurt. Making Danish Raspberry Soup Place the gelatin and soup in a large bowl. Add the boiling water gradually, stirring as you add, to dissolve the gelatin. Add the raspberries once the gelatin is dissolved.  Pour in the cold water and lemon juice. There is no need to stir just yet. Place in the refrigerator to chill. Leave for 15 to 20 minutes. Remove from the refrigerator. Stir the soup just prior to serving. Serve. If wished, add a swirl of sour cream and spice up with a little nutmeg. Making Blueberry Soup Put the all of the ingredients except for the cornstarch, vanilla and toppings into a heavy based saucepan.  Cook over medium-high heat. Stir frequently. Bring to a gentle boil. Upon boiling, immediately reduce the heat to a simmer. Simmer until the blueberries are tender. This will take about 5 minutes. Use a potato masher to mash the berries. They don't need to be smooshed, just lightly mashed. Pour into serving bowls.  Serve. Top with a drizzle of the yogurt and a handful of granola or muesli if wished. Making Rosehip Soup Cut the rosehips in half. Scoop out all of the seeds and hairy bits––these parts are bitter and/or inedible. Helpers are a good idea at this stage as it will be slow going. Place the rosehip skins into a heavy-based saucepan.  Bring to the boil. Then reduce and simmer for 30 minutes or until softened. Bring to the boil again. Boil for 15 minutes or until the liquid is reduced. Place the rosehips in a food processor. Pulse to puree. Push the puree through cheesecloth or muslin. Return the puree to the saucepan. Add the sugar. Add a little water to the cornstarch (cornflour). Mix to make a paste. Gradually add this paste to the simmering puree. Simmer until the soup thickens, about 10 to 15 minutes. Serve. Pour into serving bowls. Add a dollop of whipped cream or yogurt. Swedish diners like to break some almond macaroons over the top for crunch and flavor.
